The history of the diamond trade in southern Africa dates back to the late 19th century, when diamonds were first discovered in the region. The discovery of diamonds in Griqualand West, South Africa, in 1867, triggered a diamond rush that led to the establishment of numerous diamond mines in the region.

The diamond mines were initially controlled by private entrepreneurs, who enjoyed a great deal of autonomy in their operations. However, in 1888, the British South Africa Company (BSAC) secured a concession from the king of Matabeleland, Lobengula, to mine diamonds in his territory. The company, led by Cecil Rhodes, established the De Beers Consolidated Mines to control the diamond trade in the region.

Under Rhodes' leadership, De Beers went on to dominate the diamond industry in southern Africa, instituting strict controls on the production, distribution, and pricing of diamonds. The company's goal was to maintain a stable supply of diamonds and a steady demand, so as to maintain high prices for the gemstones.

Over the years, De Beers expanded its operations in southern Africa, establishing mines in Botswana, Namibia, and other countries. The company also invested heavily in marketing and advertising, creating a global demand for diamonds, which it could supply through its extensive network of mines.

In the 20th century, the diamond industry in southern Africa underwent significant changes, as more countries gained independence and took control of their natural resources. De Beers also faced increased competition from other diamond producers, such as Russia, which emerged as a major supplier of diamonds.

Today, the diamond trade in southern Africa remains a major industry, with countries such as Botswana and Namibia heavily reliant on diamond exports for their economies. However, the industry remains controversial, with concerns about human rights abuses and environmental damage associated with diamond mining.
